text: And blessed be the most high God, which hath delivered thine enemies into thy hand. And he gave him tithes of all.
text_kjv: And blessed be the most high God, which hath delivered thine enemies into thy hand. And he gave him tithes of all.
text_niv: And blessed be God Most High,who delivered your enemies into your hand.”Then Abram gave him a tenth of everything.
text_esv: and blessed be God Most High, who has delivered your enemies into your hand!”  And Abram gave him a tenth of everything.
text_nlt: And blessed be God Most High,who has defeated your enemies for you.” Then Abram gave Melchizedek a tenth of all the goods he had recovered.
text_msg: And blessed be The High God,who handed your enemies over to you.Abram gave him a tenth of all the recovered plunder.
text_nasb: And blessed be God Most High, Who has delivered your enemies into your hand.' He gave him a tenth of all.
context: Genesis 14 describes a war between several kings in Mesopotamia and the kings of Sodom, Gomorrah, and surrounding cities. Lot, Abraham's nephew, was captured during this conflict when Sodom was plundered. Abraham, upon hearing of Lot's capture, mustered his trained fighting force (318 men) and pursued the victorious armies, defeating them and rescuing Lot and the other captives, along with their possessions. Abraham's victory was not attributed to his own strength but to God's intervention. Upon his return, Abraham was met by two figures: the king of Sodom and Melchizedek, king of Salem and a priest of God Most High (El Elyon). Melchizedek brought bread and wine, symbolizing sustenance and fellowship, and blessed Abraham, acknowledging God's role in Abraham's victory. This event highlights the interconnectedness of religious and political authority in the ancient Near East, where kings often held priestly roles or had close relationships with religious figures. The term 'tithes' refers to a tenth part of possessions, given as an offering. Tithing predates the Mosaic Law and demonstrates recognition of God's ownership and provision. The fact that Abraham, a figure revered in Judaism, Christianity, and Islam, offered tithes to Melchizedek elevates the significance of this act, suggesting a divinely ordained practice of honoring God with one's resources. This encounter with Melchizedek, a mysterious figure who appears without genealogy or prior mention, adds a layer of complexity and theological significance to the narrative, prefiguring the priestly role of Christ.
meaning: Genesis 14:20 is a pivotal verse in understanding the nature of God's blessings and humanity's response to divine favor. Melchizedek's blessing, 'Blessed be the most high God, which hath delivered thine enemies into thy hand,' directly attributes Abraham's military victory to God's power. This emphasizes that victory is not achieved through human strength or strategy alone, but through divine intervention. The title 'most high God' (El Elyon) underscores God's sovereignty and supremacy over all creation. It also acknowledges that all power and authority ultimately derive from Him. Abraham's subsequent act of giving 'him tithes of all' demonstrates his recognition of God's ownership and provision. Tithing, in this context, is not merely a financial transaction; it is an act of worship and gratitude. It signifies acknowledging God's role as the source of all blessings and a commitment to honor Him with a portion of the increase. This passage reveals a profound principle: God provides the victory, and humanity responds with gratitude and obedience. The fact that Abraham gives tithes to Melchizedek, a priest of God Most High, reinforces the idea that tithes are an offering to God, mediated through His appointed representatives. Furthermore, this encounter with Melchizedek prefigures the ultimate priesthood of Jesus Christ, as highlighted in the book of Hebrews. Melchizedek serves as a type of Christ, a priest-king who offers bread and wine and receives tithes from Abraham. The verse thus establishes a theological foundation for understanding God's sovereignty, humanity's response to divine blessing, and the enduring significance of the priestly office.
application: Genesis 14:20 offers profound practical applications for modern believers. Firstly, it reminds us to acknowledge God's hand in our successes. Whether it's a career advancement, a financial windfall, or overcoming a personal challenge, we should recognize that our abilities and opportunities ultimately stem from God's grace and provision. This requires cultivating a posture of humility and gratitude, constantly acknowledging that we are stewards of God's blessings, not owners. Secondly, the verse calls us to practice faithful stewardship by honoring God with our resources. While the specific practice of tithing (giving 10% of our income) is debated among Christians, the underlying principle remains relevant. We should intentionally and sacrificially give back to God a portion of what He has entrusted to us, supporting the work of the church, ministries, and those in need. This giving should be motivated by a desire to honor God and express our gratitude for His provision, not out of obligation or guilt. Thirdly, we should cultivate a deeper understanding of God's sovereignty and trust in His plans, even when facing challenges. Abraham's victory was not guaranteed, but he trusted in God's power to deliver him. Similarly, we can find strength and hope in knowing that God is in control, even when circumstances seem bleak. Finally, the encounter with Melchizedek reminds us to appreciate the priestly role of Christ, who intercedes for us and offers us access to God's grace. We can draw near to God through Christ, offering our lives as a living sacrifice, expressing our gratitude and devotion through acts of service, worship, and obedience. Living out Genesis 14:20 means acknowledging God's sovereignty, practicing faithful stewardship, trusting in His plans, and appreciating the priestly ministry of Christ.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for your blessings and for the victories you grant us in life, both big and small. Forgive me for the times I have taken credit for achievements that were ultimately made possible by your grace. Help me to cultivate a heart of gratitude and humility, always acknowledging your hand in my life. Teach me to be a faithful steward of the resources you have entrusted to me, generously giving back to you and supporting those in need. Strengthen my trust in your sovereignty, especially during times of hardship and uncertainty. Remind me of the priestly ministry of Jesus Christ, who intercedes for me and offers me access to your presence. May my life be a reflection of your love and grace, and may my actions bring glory to your name. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Melchizedek is significant because he is a priest-king who blesses Abraham, a foundational figure in Judaism and Christianity. His unique position prefigures Christ's dual role as priest and king, highlighting a divine order transcending temporal hierarchies.

faqs.answer: 'Most high God' emphasizes God's supreme authority and power over all creation and other gods. It underscores His sovereignty and absolute dominion, highlighting His unique position above all else.
faqs.question: Q3: What is the significance of the phrase 'most high God' (El Elyon)?

faqs.answer: Abraham's offering tithes signifies his recognition of God as the source of his victory and blessings. It demonstrates his faith by acknowledging God's ownership and provision, trusting that God will continue to provide.
faqs.question: Q4: How does Abraham's action demonstrate faith in God?

faqs.answer: Abraham's willingness to fight for Lot demonstrates compassion and a sense of responsibility for his family. It exemplifies standing up for what is right and protecting those who are vulnerable, even at personal risk.
